Fiction from the Archives

More by this author »

Jamaica Kincaid

Selected Stories

  • Lucy

    “I had begun to see the past like this: there is a line; you can draw it yourself, or sometimes it gets drawn for you.”

  • At the Bottom of the River

    “I had no name for the thing I had become, so new was it to me.”

  • Girl

    “This is how to love a man, and if this doesn’t work there are other ways.”
Photograph from Shutterstock
Jamaica Kincaid, who moved from Antigua to New York at seventeen, has been writing for The New Yorker since 1974. Her first story in the magazine, “Girl,” a single six-hundred-and-eighty-five-word sentence, delivered by a mother to her daughter, is a chiselled jewel, precise, punishing, and electric with the power of language. As Edwidge Danticat noted on the New Yorker Fiction Podcast, Kincaid “expanded the idea, the notion, of what you can do with fiction.”

Girl
